case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 451 of 1960 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 451 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 18, 1957 of the Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 8 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 18, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 8 of 1957.

facts.text: N. Rajagopal Sastri and D. Gupta appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: N. Rajagopal Sastri and D. Gupta, for the appellant.

facts.text: Bishan Narain, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Bishan Narain, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the respondent,.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on February 21, 1961 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. February 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-

facts.text: Appeal pursuant to certificate of the High Court of Bombay under s. 66A(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal pursuant to a certificate of the High Court of Bombay under s. 66A 2  of the Indian Income- tax Act  hereinafter called the Act  .

facts.text: For the year of assessment 1949-50 the respondent was assessed to Rs. 1,80,646/14/- as income-tax and super-tax on June 2, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: For the year of assessment 1949-50 the respondent was assessed to a sum of Rs. 1,80,646/14/ as income-tax and super-tax on June 2, 1954.

facts.text: Notice of demand under s. 29 of the Act served on respondent to pay the amount on or before July 17, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: A numberice of demand under s. 29 of the Act was served on the respondent to pay that amount on or before July 17, 1954.

facts.text: Respondent allowed to pay by instalments on his application.

anchor.surface_text: On his application the respondent was allowed to pay by instalments.

facts.text: Last instalment of Rs. 30,646/14/- payable on or before March 20, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The last instalment of Rs. 30,646/14/- was payable on or before March 20, 1955.

facts.text: Default in payment of the last instalment.

anchor.surface_text: As there was a default in the payment of this instalment

facts.text: Income-tax Officer imposed penalty of Rs. 3,000 under s. 46(1) on March 31, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax Officer on March 31, 1955 imposed a penalty of Rs. 3,000/ under s. 46 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent filed appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner on April 20, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On April 20, 1955 the respondent filed an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

facts.text: Last instalment not paid by April 20, 1955, paid on May 16, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: but by that date the last instalment had number been paid and it was paid on May 16, 1955.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer raised preliminary objection that appeal was incompetent because last instalment not paid.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer raised a preliminary objection before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner that the appeal was number companypetent because the last instalment of the tax had number been paid.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the preliminary objection.

anchor.surface_text: This was upheld by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal against AAC order.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the respondent took an appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal

facts.text: Tribunal held right of appeal conferred by s.30(1), not taken away by s.30(2), only remedy barred.

anchor.surface_text: which held that the right of appeal was companyferred by s. 30 1  of the Act and is number taken away by s. 30 2  of the Act, only the remedy is barred.

facts.text: Tribunal held appeal became good as soon as tax paid on May 16, 1955, deemed preferred on that date, AAC to decide condonation of delay.

anchor.surface_text: It further held that as the right had number been destroyed the appeal became good appeal as soon as the assessee paid the arrears of tax and the only effect of the payment on May 16, 1955, was that the appeal shall be taken to have been preferred before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on that date and it was then for the Appellate Assistant Commissioner to decide whether it was a fit case for extension of time and companydonation of delay.

facts.text: Tribunal directed Appellate Assistant Commissioner to dispose of the appeal in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal therefore directed the. Appellate Assistant Commissioner to dispose of the appeal in accordance with law.

facts.text: At instance of Commissioner of Income-tax, Tribunal stated question of law to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income-tax, who is. the appellant before us, the Tribunal stated the following question of law to the High Court-

facts.text: Question referred: Whether appeal filed on 20th April 1955 before AAC became proper and complete though barred by limitation and AAC should decide condonation of delay.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the appeal filed before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on 20th April, 1955, became a proper and companyplete appeal though barred by limitation and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner should have decided the question of the companydonation of delay ?

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed against High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax has companye in appeal against this judgment.

facts.text: Appellant contended that 'no appeal shall lie' means no right of appeal till tax paid, memorandum cannot be filed, merely waste paper.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention which was raised before us was that these words mean that there is numberright of appeal till the tax is paid and therefore if the tax has number been paid the memorandum of appeal cannot be filed and if filed it is merely a waste paper.

issues.text: Whether the appeal filed before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on 20th April, 1955, became a proper and complete appeal though barred by limitation and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner should have decided the question of the condonation of delay ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the appeal filed before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on 20th April, 1955, became a proper and companylete appeal though barred by limitation and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner should have decided the question of the

issues.text: Whether the words 'no appeal shall lie' in the proviso to s. 30(1) mean that there is no right of appeal till the tax is paid and therefore the memorandum of appeal cannot be filed until the tax is paid

anchor.surface_text: The controversy between the parties revolves round the words numberappeal shall lie. The companytention which was raised before us was that these words mean that there is numberright of appeal till the tax is paid and therefore if the tax has number been paid the memorandum of appeal cannot be filed and if filed it is merely a waste paper.

arguments.claim: The appeal was not competent because the last instalment of the tax had not been paid

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer raised a preliminary objection before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner that the appeal was not competent because the last instalment of the tax had not been paid.

anchor.surface_text: which held that the right of appeal was conferred by s. 30 1  of the Act and is number taken away by s. 30 2  of the Act, only the remedy is barred.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 1  in regard to the payment of taxes in the following Words Provided that numberappeal shall lie against an order under sub-section  1  of section 46

arguments.court_reasoning: Exactly the effect of proviso to s.30(1) read with s.30(2)

arguments.claim: The words 'no appeal shall lie' mean that there is no right of appeal till the tax is paid and therefore if the tax has not been paid the memorandum of appeal cannot be filed and if filed it is merely a waste paper

anchor.surface_text: The contention which was raised before us was that these words mean that there is no right of appeal till the tax is paid and therefore if the tax has number been paid the memorandum of appeal cannot be filed and if filed it is merely a waste paper.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the parties revolves round the words numberappeal shall lie. The companytention which was raised before us was that these words mean that there is nu

arguments.court_reasoning: Meaning is not that no memorandum can be presented; appeal not held properly filed until tax paid; deemed filed on payment date if after limitation

arguments.claim: The meaning of the words 'no appeal shall lie' in the proviso is not that no memorandum of appeal can be presented; appeal not properly filed until tax paid; if tax paid after limitation, deemed filed on payment date for condonation

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the meaning of the words numberappeal shall lie in the proviso is number that numbermemorandum of appeal can be presented. All that it means is that the appeal will number be-held to be properly filed until the tax has been paid. If, for instance, the memorandum of appeal is filed on the 20th day, i.e.,. 10 days before the period of limitation expires and the tax is paid within the rest of the 10 days, the appeal will be a proper appeal it will be within time and numberquestion of limitation will arise but if the tax is paid after the period of limitation has expired it will be taken to have been filed on the day when the tax is paid even though the memorandum of appeal was presented earlier and within the period of limitation., The question, will then have to be decided whether there was sufficient cause for companydonation of delay and that is exactly what the Tribunal had ordered and that in our opinion is the effect of the proviso to s. 30 1  read with sub-s.  2  of s. 30 of the Act.

arguments.claim: It is unnecessary to refer to the two cases referred to by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary therefore to refer to the two cases referred to by the High Court, i.e., Raja of Venkatagiri v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1  and Kamdar Brothers v. Commissioner of Income-tax  2 .

holdings.text: In our opinion the meaning of the words 'no appeal shall lie' in the proviso is not that no memorandum of appeal can be presented. All that it means is that the appeal will not be held to be properly filed until the tax has been paid. If [...] the tax is paid after the period of limitation has expired it will be taken to have been filed on the day when the tax is paid [...] The question, will then have to be decided whether there was sufficient cause for condonation of delay and that is exactly what the Tribunal had ordered and that in our opinion is the effect of the proviso to s. 30(1) read with sub-s. (2) of s. 30 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the meaning of the words numberappeal shall lie in the proviso is number that numbermemorandum of appeal can be presented. All that it means is that the appeal will number be-held to be properly filed until the tax has been paid. If, for instance, the memorandum of appeal is filed on the 20th day, i.e.,. 10 days before the period of limitation expires and the tax is paid within the rest of the 10 days, the appeal will be a proper appeal it will be within time and numberquestion of limitation will arise but if the tax is paid after the period of limitation has expired it will be taken to have been filed on the day when the tax is paid even though the memorandum of appeal was presented earlier and within the period of limitation., The question, will then have to be decided whether there was sufficient cause for companydonation of delay and that is exactly what the Tribunal had ordered and that in our opinion is the effect of the proviso to s. 30 1  read with sub-s.  2  of s. 30 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation distinguishes presentation of memorandum from proper filing of appeal; harmonizes proviso to s.30(1) with s.30(2) limitation and condonation provisions; rejects absolute bar on right or filing pre-payment.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary therefore to refer to the two cases referred to by the High Court, i.e., Raja of Venkatagiri v. Commissioner of Income-tax and Kamdar Brothers v. Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary therefore to refer to the two cases referred to by the High Court, i.e., Raja of Venkatagiri v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1  and Kamdar Brothers v. Commissioner of Income-tax  2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Own interpretation of statute resolves issue without need for prior precedents.

The concept of the surviving statutory right of appeal despite the proviso addresses the issue concerning the propriety and completeness of the filed appeal despite the bar.

The concept that the right of appeal survives the proviso, which only bars the remedy until compliance, addresses the issue of whether the proviso eliminates the right or prevents filing the memorandum until tax is paid.
